text:
Polenka wept. Sonia prayed softly, her own tears falling. 

“Why hasn’t she spoken to me?” Raskolnikov thought. 

The sunlight brightened the room. The priest read, “Give rest, oh Lord….” Raskolnikov stayed through the service. 

Afterward, he approached Sonia. She took his hands and rested her head on his shoulder. 

He felt bewildered. No disgust, no tremor in her touch. 

Sonia said nothing. He pressed her hand and left. 

Misery enveloped him. He craved solitude but never felt alone. 

He wandered into the woods, but unease followed him. 

He returned to the town, seeking the crowd. 

In a tavern, he listened to songs, remembering joy.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov experiences a profound sense of misery and confusion as he grapples with his feelings for Sonia and his inability to find solitude or peace.
